headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the L-3 Communications Holdings, Inc. Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Jennifer Beugelmans
componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to the L-3 Communications Holdings, Inc. Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Mr. Jennifer Beugelmans of Joele Frank. Ms. Beugelmans, the floor is yours, ma'am.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thanks for joining us for L-3's Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With me are Michael Strianese, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Ralph D'Ambrosio, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. After their
componenttext:
Good morning, and thanks for joining us for L-3's Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With me are Michael Strianese, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Ralph D'Ambrosio, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. After their formal remarks, management will be available to take your questions. 
Please note that during this conference call, management will reiterate forward-looking statements that were made in the press release issued this morning. Please refer to this press release as well as the company's SEC filings for a more detailed description of the factors that may cause actual results to differ materially from those anticipated. Please also note that this call is being simultaneously broadcast over the Internet. 
I would now like to turn the call over to Michael Strianese. Mike, please go ahead.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you. Thanks for joining us. So I'd like to start by recognizing our employees from all their hard work this past year. Every day, they demonstrate a consistent focus on performance and a strong commitment to our customers. Thanks t
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you. Thanks for joining us. So I'd like to start by recognizing our employees from all their hard work this past year. Every day, they demonstrate a consistent focus on performance and a strong commitment to our customers. Thanks to their collective efforts, we had a solid fourth quarter, underscored by strong earnings per share, cash flow and funded orders. 
Operationally, we continue to execute well on our programs, increase our international and commercial business and create value for shareholders through some disciplined capital allocation and our dividend strategy. Amid persistent challenging conditions, we continue to manage our business effectively, exceeding our 2014 financial plans for orders. Our balance sheet is strong, and we continue our robust cash generation. 
Our net sales for the quarter were $3.2 billion, a 1% decrease from the fourth quarter of 2013. Net sales for the full year were $12.1 billion. Declining U.S. Government sales were partially offset by an increase in net sales to international and commercial customers of 2% to $1 billion in the fourth quarter compared to $980 million year-over-year. This increase puts us at 31% international and commercial sales for the quarter, which would be about 28% pro forma, excluding the MSI divestiture, which we expect to close during the second quarter of 2015, and I'll talk about that in more detail in a few minutes. 
We continue to pursue a number of international and commercial opportunities across the company. Diluted earnings per share for the quarter increased by 16% year-over-year to $2.36 compared with $2.04. Diluted EPS for the year was $7.56. Funded orders were $3.4 billion, a 14% increase year-over-year. Funded orders for the year were $12.1 billion. Our book-to-bill ratio was 1.05x in the quarter, and it was 1 for 2014, reflecting the continued strength of our market positions and exceeding our expectations for 2014. 
Operating income for the fourth quarter declined by 1% or $3 million compared to last year to $303 million. Operating margin decreased by 10 basis points to 9.4% compared to 9.5% in the fourth quarter of 2013. Our free cash flow for the quarter was approximately $452 million, bringing our full year 2014 cash flow to a very robust $946 million. 
While there are clear signs that the U.S. defense industry downturn is approaching the bottom, our strategy remains unchanged. We are focused on providing value through innovative and affordable solutions for all of our customers. An important part of that strategy is continually reshaping our portfolio to reflect our customers' priorities and bring new efficiencies to our core businesses. 
During the fourth quarter, we announced a definitive agreement to sell our Marine Systems International or MSI business. The sale of MSI will sharpen our core businesses and also improve our margins on a consolidated basis. Also, our recently completed acquisition of MITEQ reflects a key element of our continuing portfolio-shaping strategy to enhance and augment our business capabilities with niche acquisitions that create long-term value for our shareholders. 
Now some brief comments about the performance of our business segments, including significant awards and milestones starting with Electronic Systems. At Electronic Systems, net sales for the fourth quarter increased by $80 million or 6% on a year-over-year basis. Operating income was up 6% from $145 million to $154 million. Overall, within Electronic Systems, we are well positioned to increase market share across a variety of business areas, and we remain focused on driving margin expansion in the near term. We have excellent performance, and continuous improvement will help us achieve this goal. 
Here are some highlights for the quarter. We continue to receive strong orders for our Wescam sensors from the U.S. Military and key international customers, including the Royal Saudi Air Force, the U.A.E., The People's Democratic Republic of Algeria and AFRICOM. And we continue to make on-time deliveries through our global customer base, including a recent successful delivery to Egypt. 
We are steadily gaining market share in Aviation Products. We received a contract for avionics in support of the U.S. Army's U860 program, where we will be providing standby instrument systems. Also, L-3 entered into a reseller agreement to supply avionics for Boeing 737 and 767 aircraft, which includes component repair and maintenance support. Related to this, we also entered into an agreement for the distribution of L-3 Aviation Products here in the U.S. 
We also received the first purchase order for our new links -- multi-links surveillance system. This single box ADS-B solution is a new product line for the general aviation marketplace, which will be rolled out and marketed in the first quarter of 2015. We recorded a strategic win for specialized directed energy products for the space and missile command and an order for our antisubmarine work vessel system for Indonesia. Under a 5-year program, we were awarded a 9 ship set order for switch gears and circuit breakers for the Virginia class submarine. In our Security & Detection Systems business, we've been selected to provide a new network for radiation detection capability for Dutch Customs. Additionally, in Saudi Arabia, we are providing mobile scanning machines for customs use. 
In Warrior Systems, we saw continued orders for our night vision equipment from both commercial and military customers, including SOCOM. We continued on-time deliveries for shipments through the fourth quarter and received orders for thermal systems from the U.S. Army. And our Link business was selected to provide contract training and simulation services for that E3 program. 
Moving on to Aerospace Systems. Net sales in the segment increased $13 million or about 1% compared to the 2013 fourth quarter. Operating income was up 2% year-over-year. Platform and Logistics Solutions accounted for $8 million of the sales increase, and the remaining $5 million to from ISR Systems. Our performance on legacy programs, especially at ISR Systems, has been outstanding, and this fuels our business along with our ISR and international modernization work. 
Going forward, we see a strong pipeline of opportunities to increase our business space in this area. Key wins in the quarter included a 5-year program for support special mission aircraft operating out of airport base. We were selected to upgrade communication systems on the C32 and C40 aircraft for the DoD and to support a data link upgrade initiative for the C37 aircraft. Internationally, we received continued funding for our work upgrading Argentina's C-130 fleet, and our work on the U.K. Airseeker program continues to proceed very well. We are expecting to deliver our second of 3 aircraft ahead of schedule and on budget. 
Our tactical ISR continues to advance and deliver solid performance metrics. We receive funding for our ISR integration work in Yemen. Our SPYDR platform continues to operate at more than 300 hours per month for its DoD customers, with an overall mission availability rate of 98.8%, and we are meeting our milestones with our Middle East customers. Additionally, we are at work on a new variant of SPYDR to address future Army and SOCOM sensor requirements. We've also been awarded a contract in support of a basic trainer and light lift aircraft initiative in Afghanistan. Performance-wise, we delivered 33 aircraft on time or ahead of schedule to a wide range of customers. 
Communication Systems. Sales in our Communication Systems segment declined by $73 million or about 14% year-over-year. We're working to improve Communication Systems operating performance, building off our unique capabilities and strong market position. Ralph will go through some of the reasons for the decline in little while, but some other highlights in the quarter are: we continue to see strong domestic and international demand for SATCOM. We also have continued orders and funding for SATCOM terminals, including the SDN light program and our Hawkeye equipment as well as an expansion of our work in Australia. We received continued funding for a variety of legacy programs, including orders for ROVER 6 and Vortex for both domestic and international customers, an additional funding for the Gray Eagle program as well as the U2 and F-35 programs. On the global op program, we received a follow-on funding, which also includes a key international opportunity with the Republic of Korea. In addition, we received continued funding for our work on the WIN-T programs as well as orders for a life-cycle upgrade. 
On the Navy side, we saw continued funding for a variety of programs, including the offshore patrol program in Canada and the rigid haul inflatable boat program for the Royal Australian Navy. We are continuing our communications upgrade work on Australia's common class submarines. Our customer reports they are extremely pleased with our progress. From the Australia MOD, we received 2 sets of orders for our traveling-wave tube equipment, and we have continued our work on the Gorgon staff program, which is now a program of record. L-3 Communications work on increments 1 and 2 of this program have been excellent, with 99% mission effectiveness since 2011. We are working with prime on the next-generation hardware for the potential Increment 3 program. 
Moving on to National Security Solutions. Net sales for the fourth quarter at the MSS segment were 15% lower or about $46 million compared to the fourth quarter of 2013. This was mainly due to reduced demand and contract completions as well as the late contract awards for international contracts and protest on U.S. Government contracts where we were the winter. These decreases were partially offset by our acquisition of the Data Tactics business. Despite the challenges in this business area, we are successfully penetrated emerging markets and gaining new customers and market share in the U.S. Government intelligence community. 
The National Security Agency awarded L-3 the Enterprise Program Management contract, or EPM, to provide systems engineering, acquisition planning, program management and financial management, the 2 of NSA's major mission areas. This was our largest contract recompete for 2014. 
We received a major win in the form of a task order to support the U.S. Army's medical communications for combat casualty care program, providing engineering and logistic support. We were selected as 1 of 3 awardees for the U.S. Navy cyber warfare development group vehicle, which is a strategic 3-year program to provide cyberspace support, cryptologic and electronic work operational capabilities. And we recorded our first-ever prime contract win with the National Geospatial Intelligence Agency as part of the ITEMS program. We've also receive follow-on funding from the Defense Threat Reduction Agency and nuclear test personnel review. This is an 8-year program. 
Now a little bit of capital allocation and acquisitions. Following our long-standing strategy of maximizing shareholder value through dividends and share repurchases, we returned $460 million in the fourth quarter compared to $444 million in the fourth quarter of '13. For the year ended December 31, we returned over $1 billion. In the fourth quarter, we purchased $410 million compared to $396 million year-over-year. This brought the total common stock repurchase for the year ended December 31 to $823 million, up from $800 million in the prior year. We will continue to implement our cash allocation strategy, which includes a prudent combination of returning cash to shareholders and common stock repurchases while still investing in the business through R&D, acquisitions, et cetera. 
While our M&A activity was limited in '14, we continue to look closely at opportunities for acquisitions that meet our criteria of adding to market share, enhancing synergies and collaboration across our business segments and delivering new and more innovative solutions to our customers. As part of the strategy, last week, we announced that we have acquired the assets of MITEQ, which will be combined with our micro business. L-3 and MITEQ will employ about 700 people and provide products from U.S. military, government agencies, prime contractors and commercial customers as well. The acquisition is expected to generate approximately $55 million in sales in 2015. This deal adds key RF microwave and low-power SATCOM products and capabilities of creates cross-selling opportunities that will expand our customer base. 
As I mentioned earlier, we continue to shape our portfolio to reflect our customers' priorities and help us achieve operational efficiencies. The sale of our Marine Systems International business is further evidence of this strategy. The MSI transaction is anticipated to be completed in the second quarter of 2015 end. Of course, it's subject to customary closing conditions and regulatory approvals. While these transactions are relatively small, they do demonstrate our commitment to finding opportunities to tailor our product mix to our customers' needs and achieve efficiencies that will help us expand. We are committed to finding opportunities to tailor our product mix, the customer needs and achieving efficiencies. 
Regarding the budget. The U.S. Government market remains a challenge in environment with ongoing budget uncertainty, but I do believe we've reached the bottom of the downturn and things will soon begin to grow. What we need our security to prove budget [indiscernible] the geopolitical issues the U.S. is facing. The defense sector contributes to our national security in close partnership with our men and women in uniform, and it's essential that our personnel have equipment readiness to fulfill their duties in this ever-dangerous environment. 
Stopping sequestration has been a difficult process within government. However, with positive signs like the '15 budget authorization and the OCO budget, we remain optimistic that our DoD customer will receive some continued sequester relief for fiscal '16 and beyond. Overall, budget stability will help with our planning process and increase the visibility of our business. We need to continue working with progress to end sequestration and appropriately fund R&D programs that will drive innovation and maintain IR&D investments. At L-3, we are continuing to work the DoD to strategically invest the new technologies that support DoD requirements and priority areas. In this regard, we are also increasing our R&D by about $20 million in 2015. Our focus areas include electronic warfare, sensor development, ISR Systems, space work, cyber and Big Data and the classified arena, which is a growing budget area. Overall, this will help improve our productivity and increase market share in the DoD business. L-3 has a diverse space, including content on nearly every DoD platform. At the same time, we continue to expand our international and commercial business to offset the challenges to our DoD business. 
With that, let me turn it over to Ralph, who'll take us through financial data in more detail.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. I'll discuss some details about the fourth quarter results and then review our 2015 initial guidance. Overall, our fourth quarter results generally exceeded our expectations, driven by strong orders, sales, earnings per share and free cas
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike. I'll discuss some details about the fourth quarter results and then review our 2015 initial guidance. Overall, our fourth quarter results generally exceeded our expectations, driven by strong orders, sales, earnings per share and free cash flow and a lower tax rate. Fourth quarter sales of $3.2 billion, only declining 1% versus the 2013 fourth quarter, and that was the high end of our most recent sales guidance range. 
Fourth quarter diluted earnings per share was $2.36 and benefited from lower tax rate, primarily due to Congress reenacting the research and experimentation or R&E credit in December, which lowered taxes by $22 million and added $0.26 to EPS. Our fourth quarter EPS was also negatively impacted by $80 million charge in Electronic Systems segment-related product specifications matter with the U.S. Government, which subtracted $0.17 from EPS. The R&E credit and the Electronic Systems charge were not assumed or expected in our most recent 2014 guidance. 
At the segment level, fourth quarter sales and margin were ahead of our most recent guidance at Communication Systems and Electronic Systems, excluding the charge for product specifications matter but below our guidance at Aerospace Systems and National Security Solutions. At Electronic Systems on Communication Systems, margins benefited from better sales volumes, cost takeout actions and improved contract performance. Communication Systems also booked and shipped some high-margin SATCOM terminals sooner than we expected. 
Conversely, at aerospace Systems, margin was negatively impacted by additional schedule slips and cost growth on 2 international aircraft modification contracts and reduced pricing and revised incentive fee structure on the new T45 training aircraft support contract, which began on October 1. 
NSS margins were lower due to high-margin international sales sliding to 2015 as well as increased spending on business development and marketing and selling expenses. Lastly, fourth quarter free cash flow was very good, totaling $452 million, resulting in full year free cash flow of almost $950 million, with an earnings to cash flow conversion of 142% and free cash flow per share of $10.77. 
Moving on to this year. Today, we provided our initial guidance for 2015. It is consistent with the preliminary outlook that we provided 3 months ago with some pluses or minuses that offset each other. Our 2015 diluted earnings per share range is $7.35 to $7.65. Included in the EPS guidance is higher pension expense versus 2014 and no Federal R&E tax credit in the tax rate. Pension expense will increase versus 2014 by $59 million, primarily due to a lower discount rate, and that is reducing EPS by $0.45. We expect consolidated sales to decline about 2% to a midpoint of $11,850,000,000 for 2015 versus last year. The Afghanistan drawdown is expected to reduce sales by approximately $250 million year-over-year, and we expect our U.S. Government business, including the DoD, to decline by about 7% and our international commercial business to offset that decline, growing also at about 7%. 
Our recently announced MITEQ acquisition adds about $55 million in sales in 2015. For operating margin, we continue to expect 2015 consolidated margin to be about 9.3% after higher pension expense, which will reduce margin by 50 basis point. Excluding the higher pension expense, we expect margins to increase in every segment with most of the increase in Aerospace Systems and NSS, which had the easier comparisons versus 2014. We had a few offsetting changes in our initial 2015 margin guidance compared to our 2015 preliminary outlook. First, the pension expense increase will be $14 million less than previously estimated, and that's due to a variety of changes and assumptions unrelated to the discount, and that's being offset by higher medical expenses of about $10 million across the company and about $5 million that will further integrate MITEQ with Microwave. The good news with respect to the MITEQ and Lower Microwave integration and consolidation is that beginning in 2016, we expect those combined companies to generate annual operating income synergies of about $5 million, which will increase 2016 operating income year-over-year in com systems by about $10 million when you factor in the $5 million that we incur in 2015 for the integration. Additionally, for 2015, we're increasing our investment in R&D by about $20 million and at U.S. Government classified markets, mostly electronic Systems, and that's to drive future sales growth and that increased investment in R&D is being offset by cost improvements elsewhere in the business and the segments. 
The 2015 tax rate is going to increase because we have no R&E credit. If the R&E credit is reenacted, it will lower the tax rate by about 220 basis points and increase EPS to 2015 by about $0.24. We ultimately expect that there will be an R&E credit for 2015. It's only a matter of when Congress enacts it. 
We expect to generate free cash flow next year -- or this year, rather, of about $925 million and that's -- that'll be cash flow per share of about $11. With respect to the capital allocation, we're still planning for initial share repurchases of $500 million. We ended 2014 with a cash balance of approximately $500 million. That's including $61 million related to MSI, which was classified as an asset held for sale, which will collect when the MSI sale is completed later on this year. So after dividends and share buyback of $500 million, we will have excess cash deploying in 2015 of up to $900 million, including the MSI sales proceeds. And that excludes cash overseas, which will only be about $125 million by the time we get to the end of 2015. 
We expect to have a book-to-bill ratio for the full year of approximately 1.0. With respect to the first quarter outlook, we expect sales to be in the $2.7 billion to $2.8 billion range; margin in the low 8% range; EPS of about $1.50. Free cash flow will be negative in the first quarter by about $100 million, similar to what it was in 2014, and the first quarter book-to-bill ratio looks like it's going to be about 0.95. 
I'd like to make a couple of points about the MSI divestiture. Because it is not reflected in our guidance that we provided today, we'll include us in the guidance when the transaction closes, but I want to let you know what the impact would be ahead of that time. So once it closes, it'll become a discontinued operation, and that will lower income from continuing operations -- or results from continuing operations at the sales line by about $500 million. It'll increase consolidated margin by 10 to 15 basis points and have about a neutral or no impact to our EPS and free cash flow guidance that we gave today for the year. So to conclude my financial review, while the DoD environment will again be challenging for this year, future budget levels are set to improve with the budget likely upturning in FY '16, which begins in October 1. We're effectively managing for the DoD downcycle. The company is resilient and healthy. We're generating robust cash flow, and we'll continue to allocate our capital and our cash flow to increase shareholder value. 
Thank you, and we'll now begin the Q&A.

So we have a lot of opportunities to either do more acquisitions or buy back more of our common stock.

componenttext: Okay. More recently, and it looks like you've been doing some more acquisitions. I mean, I guess, most of the last year, you were focused on the repo. How should we think about the priority areas, sort of the likelihood of doing some more in M&A versus stock repurchase?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, M&A continues to be a key element of our growth strategy, but as you know, with M&A for us has always been one opportunistic in that the targets or the candidates have to be available to acquire, and then they have to be fit with L-3, and lastly, an
componenttext: Well, M&A continues to be a key element of our growth strategy, but as you know, with M&A for us has always been one opportunistic in that the targets or the candidates have to be available to acquire, and then they have to be fit with L-3, and lastly, and most importantly, good economic returns on the investment. So clearly, we like to do more acquisitions, but it's going to be subject to those 3 factors I just talked about, opportunity fit and economic returns.

componenttext: Okay, great. And then the NSS segment, in particular, Mike put up 3% margin. I realize it's 200 basis points of headwind that are probably more one-off than not, but still obviously, the trend line of reducing the margin profile in every quarter in the last 4 quarters then you get to the end of the year, and you're pointing a little bit up for next year but still below where you thought you're going to start this year. So just that business, as if it sits today, is it still the business that you thought it was going to be? Is it still a business that kind of -- is the place it should be?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, this whole segment of the budget services namely has come under heavy pressure on the margins due in part to the buying power strategy and more competitions, more players willing to buy business, just the overall competitive environment, Myles. So w
componenttext: Well, this whole segment of the budget services namely has come under heavy pressure on the margins due in part to the buying power strategy and more competitions, more players willing to buy business, just the overall competitive environment, Myles. So we'd rather not see it that way. And candidly, if there's not an improvement over the next year or 2, this one may be one that we would choose to part with. But right now, we don't think that makes sense because we think prices are probably lower than we'd like to see for it to makes sense for us. And we still see strong growth in the cyber area. And we've won a bunch of new contracts in that area. I mean the new business has been robust, to say the least. The disappointment is, it's in margins that we are not interested in. We're not interested in 5% businesses. We're interested in 10% and better. And there'll become a point in time we're going to use in pursuing it even further. So we have our eye on it, and we're doing everything we can do to try to keep the costs as low as possible and get the margins up. But when that becomes absolutely pointless, I'm sure you'll see a change in strategy here.

componenttextpreview: Sure, Joe. It's Ralph. So what we explained in the discussion in the earnings release was that there were some high-margin international sales that slide to fourth quarter into the first half of 2015. So there's 2 contracts, in particular. One, we've alre
componenttext: Sure, Joe. It's Ralph. So what we explained in the discussion in the earnings release was that there were some high-margin international sales that slide to fourth quarter into the first half of 2015. So there's 2 contracts, in particular. One, we've already been selected an FMS contract. And there's been delays in getting it contracted through the U.S. Air Force, but we expect to book that order in the next month or 2. And then there's another contract which we expect to be sole-sourced on, and that's likely will be booked in the second quarter. So we still expect those high-margin orders and sales to occur. They're just going to be happening later than we expected at the time of our last guidance update for '14. But no doubt, the margins guidance that we gave for 2015 in NSS is contingent upon booking and converting those orders into sales that I just talked about.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just on the strategic level, back to  Myles' question. Mike, there's been some consolidation recently in services. There's been a lot of talk that they're subscale players. Your business isn't that big compared to other service companies. T
componenttext: Okay. And then just on the strategic level, back to  Myles' question. Mike, there's been some consolidation recently in services. There's been a lot of talk that they're subscale players. Your business isn't that big compared to other service companies. There's been talk of maybe a $4 billion or $5 billion threshold that's being where you need to be in services to be able to compete. How do you feel about that? Is this just, I mean if it's not going after badly priced business? Or is it just you're not your big enough?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the comment you just made about $4 billion to $5 billion to compete, I don't buy it because we've won a pretty healthy book of business this year beating many larger players, so I think it's really your performance -- your peers' performance and you
componenttext: Well, the comment you just made about $4 billion to $5 billion to compete, I don't buy it because we've won a pretty healthy book of business this year beating many larger players, so I think it's really your performance -- your peers' performance and your capabilities, what it take to win. I think that the margins adjust the current state of play in this segment of the business with the government. I mean I don't see, really, many players double-digit margins in this area, so I don't know if that's a scale issue versus more a bunch of better buying power and customer just not being in a position to want to pay much more. I mean everything is going to price, and it's not an area where our past performance is showing doing a lot for us. I think we're close to low price without willing to bid much lower on anything. So I think in terms of cost-cutting, we're in operation to begin with. So unless we're able to win business that offers high-S margins, I don't need a lot of opportunity to grow margins much more than where they are.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one more, just high level. I thought you said, Ralph, that in your plan for the year, the sales domestically you expect to be down 7% and that to be partially or largely offset by 7% growth in the international and commercial realm? An
componenttext: Okay. And then just one more, just high level. I thought you said, Ralph, that in your plan for the year, the sales domestically you expect to be down 7% and that to be partially or largely offset by 7% growth in the international and commercial realm? And so on the domestic [indiscernible] I think that's a little bit lower than some of the other companies we cover in what we're looking for a the budget outlays. Is there a way to characterize where you think your falling under, what the industry is doing more broadly? And then is that what you're attacking with your R&D or how are you planning to compensate?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I did say that we expect our DoD sales to decline by about 7% this year versus 2014. And I recall the base DoD business, which doesn't include the Afghanistan work and the drawdown impacts that we're going to encounter this year. The DoD business
componenttext: Okay. So I did say that we expect our DoD sales to decline by about 7% this year versus 2014. And I recall the base DoD business, which doesn't include the Afghanistan work and the drawdown impacts that we're going to encounter this year. The DoD business is declining about 4%, so it goes from minus 4 to minus 7 because of the $250 million of sales that are going to decline related to draw down from Afghanistan. Traditionally, within that 4% reduction, which is roughly about $300 million at the 4% level, about $100 million of it is due to some legacy DoD platforms ending or being curtailed in terms of fleet size within the platform solutions sector in our Aerospace Systems segment. And I talked about this from the last conference call, and it's a few programs. In particular, it's the U.S. Navy P3 business, which is declining as there were transitions to the new platform, P8. The DoD is planning to reduce the size of the call fleet, probably halving it if the sequester remains in effect, and hopefully, that won't happen but that's something we're seeing in 2015. And then lastly, we still have a little sales fleet to decline in 2015 that come from the decision to retire the JCA fleet a couple of years ago at the beginning of cuts and the DoD downturn. So those are the anomalies there. So if you take away the drawdown and then take away dose legacy programs that are ending, our DoD business is only declining about 2.5% or so year-over-year.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's mostly going to go into Electronic Systems. I'd say $14 million or $15 million of it in that segment and then the rest of it split between aerospace and communication systems. We're stepping up the investment because we see very good medium-term and
componenttext: It's mostly going to go into Electronic Systems. I'd say $14 million or $15 million of it in that segment and then the rest of it split between aerospace and communication systems. We're stepping up the investment because we see very good medium-term and long-term growth opportunities in the classified markets with the U.S. Government and we're putting on money where those opportunities are. And hopefully, that will lead to good sales growth a couple of years out.

componenttext: So the other thing, too, is if you look at what's been happening to -- where the lag between budget outlays, so while the budgets have bottomed, if you look at the the total reduction in the budget authority since the downturn began in FY '10, the outlays haven't declined as the budgets rise. It's probably another 4, 5 percentage points in terms of outlays. I think that's mostly because of what you're seeing across most industry this year in 2015 will continue to decline in DoD sales despite the fact that the budget stabilize.

componenttext: So if you look at our working capital, the end of 2014 versus 2013, our days sales outstanding with respect to receivables was about unchanged at 71 days, but we did have improvements in reducing our investment and inventories and that led to an overall working capital improvement into 2014. In 2015 and 2016, I still expect that we're going to reduce working capital in total by, if I recall, modest amounts, I would say, $50 million to $100 million per year. And a lot of it is going to come out of Communication Systems, where for a variety of reasons, last several years, we tired of a lot of working capital and we began to liquidate at the end of 2014 and I think we'll continue to reduce working capital investment of this year and next year.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Correct. Well, listen, if the goal is to improve our consolidated margins, there's a number of ways to do that. With higher margins, you can cut cost. You can prune those operations you own whose margins are below the average, and this is part of the ladd
componenttext: Correct. Well, listen, if the goal is to improve our consolidated margins, there's a number of ways to do that. With higher margins, you can cut cost. You can prune those operations you own whose margins are below the average, and this is part of the ladder. Those that could not perform above the clip level we're looking for, by eliminating those businesses from the portfolio will bring the average higher, right? So just another thing to look at. But generally, we see this trend across any of the businesses that are in the nonproduct businesses that where the margins seems to be softer for a variety of reasons.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, Ralph, just on the ES margin, will any of this new R&D carry into 2016? And can you maybe just update us on time on you've been looking for potentially some nice margin improvement in that segment as the mix reverts back in your favor. Is that s
componenttext: And then, Ralph, just on the ES margin, will any of this new R&D carry into 2016? And can you maybe just update us on time on you've been looking for potentially some nice margin improvement in that segment as the mix reverts back in your favor. Is that still the case once you're through '15?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: To answer your question, it's yes. That's still the case. And we'll probably spend more in R&D in 2016 as well. But the way I would characterize our margin guidance for both Electronic Systems and Communication Systems that we provide today, I would say t
componenttext: To answer your question, it's yes. That's still the case. And we'll probably spend more in R&D in 2016 as well. But the way I would characterize our margin guidance for both Electronic Systems and Communication Systems that we provide today, I would say that they're conservative given that we're at the beginning of the year. We still expect that those are going to drive core margin expansion for the entire company. And if you recall, last year, at systems, for example, we started the year with 11.1% our margin guidance. And we ultimately did 12% if you take away the charge for the product specification matter, which is a nonrecurring item. So we have similar upside to margins in those segments for 2015 as well.

componenttext: This is part Mike and part Ralph. If I look at the different sectors here and we have the product specification matter in ES. You had unfavorable contract performance on the head of state aircraft in aerospace. You had unfavorable contract performance on price development contracts and communication. So for Mike, I mean is there something here that we ought to worry about given obviously what happened last summer from a management perspective? And then for Ralph, if you could play out additional risk that might be associated with these charges as they go forward?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, George, I think that periodically, over time, business occasionally run into a problem program here and there, and I wouldn't read any more than just the normal cycle of events. It's unfortunate but they happen from time to time. I think our managem
componenttext: Well, George, I think that periodically, over time, business occasionally run into a problem program here and there, and I wouldn't read any more than just the normal cycle of events. It's unfortunate but they happen from time to time. I think our management is strongly focused on delivering the top shelf performance to their customers and will continue to do so. I would say that one characteristic when you get into heavily competitive clients is a little more risk is taken. I wouldn't say that's a trend that we're seeing across the businesses where people have stretched too thinly on taking too much risk on some of the programs, but we watch that all the time. We spent a lot of time looking at bids before they go out to make sure that's not occurring. We don't believe that it is. And I think all of these items will be remedied, and our people will learn from them and they won't to be repeated. There you go.

componenttextpreview: Okay. So most of the negative contract performance in the fourth quarter that I talked about on those 2 international aircraft modifications contracts pertains to freight modification work we're doing on a couple of 747-8s. One is -- one of those contract
componenttext: Okay. So most of the negative contract performance in the fourth quarter that I talked about on those 2 international aircraft modifications contracts pertains to freight modification work we're doing on a couple of 747-8s. One is -- one of those contracts present most of the problems, and we've had some issues and we're behind schedule, but we expect to make the delivery of that aircraft in second quarter of this year. And so we don't expect it to be a continuing problem in terms of adverse impacts to our P&L in the Aerospace Systems sector. And to give you little more detail, about $5 million of the charge pertains to liquidated damages that the contract requirements for being late on schedule, and we're going to try to negotiate some of those damages because there's been some impacts that cause this degradation that don't emanate from the company. So if we can do that, we'll have some opportunity there. And then with respect to T45 program, I think that we adequately calibrated it in our guidance for 2015, so I think we're sufficiently providing for any additional risks on any of those items.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. Well, thanks. Once again, I'd like to acknowledge for the strong, consistent performance of our employees. They did an outstanding job of executing and delivering value to customers and shareholders. Our strategy of increasing market share an
componenttext:
Okay. Great. Well, thanks. Once again, I'd like to acknowledge for the strong, consistent performance of our employees. They did an outstanding job of executing and delivering value to customers and shareholders. Our strategy of increasing market share and growing the business internationally and commercially is working. It's yielding key wins and market share gains. Our international and commercial percentage sales went from just 18% to over 30% in just 3 years, and we are well positioned to take advantage of emerging opportunities that result from portfolio adjustments across the industry. We believe that the bottom of the downturn is within sight and have taken strategic step to take advantage of opportunities that the upturn is certain to bring. Events unfolding around the world show the the strong U.S. commitment is needed, which will continue to drive the demand for L-3's market-leading products in ISR communications, electronics and security. Our strong funded backlog of projects are solid growth prospects. Our agility and innovation continue to differentiate L-3 with the ability to move quickly and to deliver targeted and affordable solutions in the dynamic environment. 
So with that, we look forward to speaking with you again at our next call in April. Thanks.

Good day, and welcome to the L-3 Communications Holdings, Inc. Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2014 Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference call over to Ms. Jennifer Beugelmans of Joele Frank. Ms. Beugelmans, the floor is yours, ma'am.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thanks for joining us for L-3's Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With me are Michael Strianese, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Ralph D'Ambrosio, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. After their
componenttext:
Good morning, and thanks for joining us for L-3's Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With me are Michael Strianese, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Ralph D'Ambrosio, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. After their formal remarks, management will be available to take your questions. 
Please note that during this conference call, management will reiterate forward-looking statements that were made in the press release issued this morning. Please refer to this press release, as well as the company's SEC filings for a more detailed description of the factors that may cause actual results to differ materially from those anticipated. 
Please also note that this call is being simultaneously broadcast over the Internet. 
I would now like to turn the call over to Michael Strianese. Mike, please go ahead.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you. Thanks for joining us. I'd like to start by recognizing our employees for all their hard work this past year. Every day, they demonstrate a consistent focus on performance and a strong commitment to our customers. Thanks to th
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you. Thanks for joining us. I'd like to start by recognizing our employees for all their hard work this past year. Every day, they demonstrate a consistent focus on performance and a strong commitment to our customers. Thanks to their collective efforts. We had a solid fourth quarter underscored by strong earnings per share, cash flow and funded orders. 
Operationally, we continue to execute well on our programs, increase our international and commercial business and create value for shareholders through some disciplined capital allocation and our dividend strategy. Amid persistent challenging conditions, we continue to manage our business effectively, exceeding our 2014 financial plans for orders. Our balance sheet is strong and we continue our robust cash generation. 
Our net sales for the quarter were $3.2 billion, a 1% decrease from the fourth quarter of 2013. Net sales for the full year were $12.1 billion. Declining U.S. government sales were partially offset by an increase in net sales to international and commercial customers of 2% to $1 billion in the fourth quarter compared to $980 million year-over-year. This increase puts us at 31% international and commercial sales for the quarter, which would be about 28% pro forma excluding the MSI divestiture, which we expect to close during the second quarter of 2015, and I'll talk about that in more detail in a few minutes. 
We continue to pursue a number of international and commercial opportunities across the company. Diluted earnings per share for the quarter increased by 16% year-over-year to $2.36 compared with $2.04. Diluted EPS for the year was $7.56. Funded orders were $3.4 billion, a 14% increase year-over-year. Funded orders for the year were $12.1 billion. Our book-to-bill ratio was 1.05x in the quarter and it was 1x for 2014, reflecting the continued strength of our market positions and exceeding our expectations for 2014. 
Operating income for the fourth quarter declined by 1% or $3 million compared to last year to $303 million. Operating margin decreased by 10 basis points to 9.4% compared to 9.5% in the fourth quarter of 2013.
Our free cash flow for the quarter was approximately $452 million, bringing our full year 2014 cash flow to a very robust $946 million. 
While there are clear signs that the U.S. defense industry downturn is approaching the bottom, our strategy remains unchanged. We are focused on providing value through innovative and affordable solutions for all of our customers. An important part of that strategy is continually reshaping our portfolio to reflect our customers' priorities and bring new efficiencies to our core businesses. 
During the fourth quarter, we announced a definitive agreement to sell our Marine Systems International or MSI business. The sale of MSI will sharpen our focus on our core businesses and also improve our margins on a consolidated basis. 
Also, our recently completed acquisition of MITEQ reflects a key element of our continuing portfolio-shaping strategy to enhance and augment our business capabilities with niche acquisitions that create long-term value for our shareholders. 
Now some brief comments about the performance of our business segments, including significant awards and milestones, starting with Electronic Systems. 
At Electronic Systems, net sales for the fourth quarter increased by $80 million or 6% on a year-over-year basis. Operating income was up 6% from $145 million to $154 million. Overall, within Electronic Systems, we are well positioned to increase market share across a variety of business areas, and we remain focused on driving margin expansion in the near-term. We have excellent performance and continuous improvement will help us achieve this goal. 
Here are some highlights for the quarter. We continued to receive strong orders from our WESCAM -- for our WESCAM sensors from the U.S. Military and key international customers, including the Royal Saudi Air Force, the UAE, the People's Democratic Republic of Algeria and AFRICOM. And we continue to make on-time deliveries through our global customer base, including a recent successful delivery to Egypt. 
We are steadily gaining market share in Aviation Products. We received a contract for avionics in support of the U.S. Army's UH-60 program, where we will be providing standby instrument systems. Also, L-3 entered into a reseller agreement to supply avionics for Boeing 737 and 767 aircraft, which includes component repair and maintenance support. Related to this, we also entered into an agreement for the distribution of L-3 Aviation Products here in the U.S. 
We also received the first purchase order for our new Lynx MultiLink Surveillance System. This single-box ADS-B solution is a new product line for the general aviation marketplace, which will be rolled out and marketed in the first quarter of 2015. We recorded a strategic win for specialized directed energy products for the phase -- for the Space and Missile Command, and an order for our HELRAS anti-submarine warfare system for Indonesia. Under a 5-year program, we were awarded a 9-ship set order for switchgear and circuit breakers for the Virginia class submarine. 
In our Security & Detection Systems business, we've been selected to provide a new network for radiation detection capability for Dutch Customs. Additionally, in Saudi Arabia, we are providing mobile scanning machines for customs use. 
In Warrior Systems, we saw continued orders for our night vision equipment from both commercial and military customers, including SOCOM. We continued on-time deliveries for shipments through the fourth quarter and received orders for thermal systems from the U.S. Army. 
And our Link business was selected to provide Contract Training and Simulation Services for the E3 program. 
Moving on to Aerospace Systems. Net sales in this segment increased $13 million or about 1% compared to the 2013 fourth quarter. Operating income was up 2% year-over-year. 
Platform & Logistics Solutions accounted for $8 million of the sales increase, and the remaining $5 million came from ISR Systems. Our performance on legacy programs, especially at ISR Systems, has been outstanding, and this fuels our business along with our tactical ISR and international modernization work. 
Going forward, we see a strong pipeline of opportunities to increase our business space in this area. Key wins in the quarter included a 5-year program for support special mission aircraft operating out of Vance Air Force Base. We were selected to upgrade communication systems on the C-32 and C-40 aircraft for the DoD, and to support a data link upgrade initiative for the C-37 aircraft. 
Internationally, we received continued funding for our work upgrading Argentina's C-130 fleet, and our work on the U.K. Air Seeker program continues to proceed very well. We are expecting to deliver our second of 3 aircraft ahead of schedule and on budget. 
Our tactical ISR work continues to advance and deliver solid performance metrics. We received funding for our ISR integration work in Yemen. Our SPYDR platform continues to operate at more than 300 hours per month for its DoD customers, with an overall mission availability rate of 98.8%, and we are meeting our milestones with our Middle East customers. Additionally, we are at work on a new variant of SPYDR to address future Army and SOCOM sensor requirements. We've also been awarded a contract in support of a basic trainer and light lift aircraft initiative in Afghanistan. Performance-wise, we delivered 33 aircraft on time or ahead of schedule to a wide range of customers. 
Communication Systems. Sales in our Communication Systems segment declined by $73 million or about 14% year-over-year. We're working to improve Communication Systems' operating performance, building off our unique capabilities and strong market position. Ralph will go through some of the reasons for the decline in little while, but some other highlights in the quarter are we continue to see strong domestic and international demand for SATCOM. We also had continued orders and funding for SATCOM terminals, including the SDN-Lite program and our Hawkeye equipment, as well as an expansion of our work in Australia. We received continued funding for a variety of legacy programs, including orders for ROVER 6 and VORTEX for both domestic and international customers, an additional funding for the Gray Eagle program, as well as the U-2 and F-35 programs.  
On the global op program, we received follow-on funding, which also includes a key international opportunity with the Republic of Korea. In addition, we received continued funding for our work on the WIN-T program, as well as orders for a life cycle upgrade. 
On the Navy side, we saw continued funding for a variety of programs, including the Offshore Patrol program in Canada and the Rigid Hull Inflatable Boat program for the Royal Australian Navy. We are continuing our communications upgrade work on Australia's Collins Class submarines. Our customer reports they are extremely pleased with our progress.  From the Israeli MoD, we received 2 sets of orders for our Traveling Wave Tube equipment. And we have continued our work on the Gorgon Stare program, which is now a program of record. L-3's communications work on Increments 1 and 2 of this program have been excellent, with 99% mission effectiveness since 2011. We are working with the prime on the next-generation hardware for the potential Increment 3 program. 
Moving on to National Security Solutions. Net sales for the fourth quarter at the NSS segment were 15% lower or about $46 million compared to the fourth quarter of 2013. This was mainly due to reduced demand and contract completions, as well as delayed contract awards for international contracts and protests on U.S. government contracts where we were the winner. These decreases were partially offset by our acquisition of the Data Tactics business. Despite the challenges in this business area, we are successfully penetrating emerging markets and gaining new customers and market share in the U.S. government intelligence community. 
The National Security Agency awarded L-3 the Enterprise Program Management contract, or EPM, to provide systems engineering, acquisition planning, program management and financial management, the 2 of NSA's major mission areas. This was our largest contract recompete for 2014. 
We received a major win in the form of a task order to support the U.S. Army's Medical Communications for Combat Casualty Care program, providing engineering and logistic support. We were selected as 1 of 3 awardees for the U.S. Navy Cyber Warfare Development Group vehicle, which is a strategic 3-year program to provide cyberspace support, cryptologic and electronic warfare operational capabilities. And we recorded our first-ever prime contract win with the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency as part of the ITEMS program. We have also received follow-on funding from the Defense Threat Reduction Agency and Nuclear Test Personnel Review. This is an 8-year program. 
Now a little bit about capital allocation and acquisitions. Following our long-standing strategy of maximizing shareholder value through dividends and share repurchases, we returned $460 million in the fourth quarter compared to $444 million in the fourth quarter of '13. For the year ended December 31, we reserved -- we returned over $1 billion.  In the fourth quarter, we repurchased $410 million compared to $396 million year-over-year. This brought the total common stock repurchase for the year ended December 31 to $823 million, up from $800 million in the prior year. We will continue to implement our cash allocation strategy, which includes a prudent combination of returning cash to shareholders and common stock repurchases, while still investing in the business through R&D, acquisitions, et cetera. 
While our M&A activity was limited in '14, we continue to look closely at opportunities for acquisitions that meet our criteria of adding to market share, enhancing synergies and collaboration across our business segments and delivering new and more innovative solutions to our customers. As part of the strategy, last week, we announced that we have acquired the assets of MITEQ, which will be combined with our Narda Microwave-East business. L-3 Narda-Miteq will employ about 700 people and provide products for the U.S. military, government agencies, prime contractors and commercial customers as well. The acquisition is expected to generate approximately $55 million in sales in 2015. This deal adds key RF microwave and low-power SATCOM products and capabilities and creates cross-selling opportunities that will expand our customer base. 
As I mentioned earlier, we continue to shape our portfolio to reflect our customers' priorities and help us achieve operational efficiencies. The sale of our Marine Systems International business is further evidence of this strategy. The MSI transaction is anticipated to be completed in the second quarter of 2015 end. Of course, it's subject to customary closing conditions and regulatory approvals. While these transactions are relatively small, they do demonstrate our commitment to finding opportunities to tailor our product mix to our customers' needs and achieve efficiencies that will help us expand. We are committed to finding opportunities to tailor our product mix, our customer needs and achieving efficiencies. 
Regarding the budget, the U.S. government market remains a challenging environment with ongoing budget uncertainty, but I do believe we have reached the bottom of the downturn and things will soon begin to grow. What we need our security-driven budget that we expect the geopolitical issues the U.S. is facing. The defense sector contributes to our national security in close partnership with our men and women in uniform, and it's essential that our personnel have equipment readiness to fulfill their duties in this ever-dangerous environment. 
Stopping sequestration has been a difficult process within government. However, with positive signs like the '15 budget authorization and the OCO budget, we remain optimistic that our DoD customer will receive some continued sequester relief for fiscal '16 and beyond. 
Overall, budget stability and growth will help with our planning process and increase the visibility of our business. We need to continue working with Congress to end sequestration and appropriately fund the R&D programs that will drive innovation and maintain IR&D investments. 
For L-3, we are continuing to work with the DoD to strategically invest the new technologies that support DoD requirements and priority areas. In this regard, we are also increasing our R&D by about $20 million in 2015. Our focus areas include electronic warfare, sensor development, ISR Systems, space work, cyber and Big Data and the classified arena, which is a growing budget area. 
Overall, this will help improve our productivity and increase market share in the DoD business. L-3 has a diverse base, including content on nearly every DoD platform. At the same time, we continue to expand our international and commercial business to offset the challenges to our DoD business. 
With that, let me turn it over to Ralph, who'll take us through financial data in more detail.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. I'll discuss some details about the fourth quarter results and then review our 2015 initial guidance. Overall, our fourth quarter results generally exceeded our expectations, driven by strong orders, sales, earnings per share and free cas
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike. I'll discuss some details about the fourth quarter results and then review our 2015 initial guidance. Overall, our fourth quarter results generally exceeded our expectations, driven by strong orders, sales, earnings per share and free cash flow and a lower tax rate. 
Fourth quarter sales were $3.2 billion, only declining 1% versus the 2013 fourth quarter, and that was the high end of our most recent sales guidance range. 
Fourth quarter diluted earnings per share was $2.36 and it benefited from a lower tax rate, primarily due to Congress reenacting the Research and Experimentation or R&E credit in December, which lowered taxes by $22 million and added $0.26 to EPS. Our fourth quarter EPS was also negatively impacted by an $18 million charge in Electronic Systems segment related to a product specifications matter with the U.S. government, which subtracted $0.17 from EPS. The R&E credit and the Electronic Systems charge were not assumed or expected in our most recent 2014 guidance. 
At the segment level, fourth quarter sales and margin were ahead of our most recent guidance at Communication Systems and Electronic Systems, excluding that charge for that product specifications matter, but below our guidance at Aerospace Systems and National Security Solutions. 
At Electronic Systems and Communication Systems, margins benefited from better sales volume, cost takeout actions, improved contract -- and improved contract performance. Communication Systems also booked and shipped some high-margin SATCOM terminals sooner than we had expected. 
Conversely, at Aerospace Systems, margin was negatively impacted by additional schedule slips and cost growth on 2 international aircraft modification contracts and reduced pricing and a revised incentive fee structure on the new T-45 training aircraft support contract, which began on October 1. 
NSS margins were lower due to high-margin international sales sliding to 2015, as well as increased spending on business development and marketing and selling expenses. 
Lastly, fourth quarter free cash flow was very good, totaling $452 million, resulting in full year free cash flow of almost $950 million, with an earnings to cash flow conversion of 142% and free cash flow per share of $10.77. 
Moving on to this year. Today, we provided our initial guidance for 2015. It is consistent with the preliminary outlook that we provided 3 months ago, with some pluses and minuses that offset each other. 
Our 2015 diluted earnings per share range is $7.35 to $7.65. Included in the EPS guidance is higher pension expense versus 2014 and no federal R&E tax credit in the tax rate. Pension expense will increase versus 2014 by $59 million, primarily due to a lower discount rate, and that is reducing EPS by $0.45. We expect consolidated sales to decline about 2% to a midpoint of $11,850,000,000 for 2015 versus last year. The Afghanistan drawdown is expected to reduce sales by approximately $250 million year-over-year, and we expect our U.S. government business, including the DoD, to decline by about 7% and our international and commercial business to offset that decline, growing also at about 7%. 
Our recently announced MITEQ acquisition adds about $55 million to sales in 2015. For operating margin, we continue to expect 2015 consolidated margin to be about 9.3% after higher pension expense, which will reduce margin by 50 basis points. Excluding the higher pension expense, we expect margins to increase in every segment, with most of the increase in Aerospace Systems and NSS, which had the easier comparisons versus 2014. 
We have a few offsetting changes in our initial 2015 margin guidance compared to our 2015 preliminary outlook. First, the pension expense increase will be $14 million less than previously estimated, and that's due to a variety of changes and assumptions unrelated to the discount, and that's being offset by higher medical expenses of about $10 million across the company and about $5 million that we'll incur to integrate MITEQ with Narda Microwave. 
The good news with respect to the MITEQ and Narda Microwave integration and consolidation is that beginning in 2016, we expect those combined companies to generate annual operating income synergies of about $5 million, which will increase 2016 operating income year-over-year in Comm Systems by about $10 million when you factor in the $5 million that we'll incur in 2015 for the integration. 
Additionally, for 2015, we're increasing our investment in R&D by about $20 million aimed at U.S. government classified markets, mostly in Electronic Systems, and that's to drive future sales growth, and that increased investment in R&D is being offset by cost improvements elsewhere in the business and the segments. 
The 2015 tax rate is going to increase because we have no R&E credit. If the R&E credit is reenacted, it will lower the tax rate by about 220 basis points and increase EPS for 2015 by about $0.24. We ultimately expect that there will be an R&E credit for 2015. It's only a matter of when Congress enacts it. 
We expect to generate free cash flow next year -- or this year, rather, of about $925 million and that's going -- that will be cash flow per share of about $11. 
With respect to the capital allocation, we're still planning for initial share repurchases of $500 million. We ended 2014 with a cash balance of approximately $500 million, that's including $61 million related to MSI, which is classified as an asset held for sale, which we'll collect when the MSI sale is completed later on this year. 
So after dividends and the share buyback of $500 million, we will have excess cash to deploy in 2015 of up to $900 million, including the MI -- MSI sales proceeds. And that excludes cash overseas, which will only be about $125 million by the time we get to the end of 2015. 
We expect to have a book-to-bill ratio for the full year of approximately 1.0x. With respect to the first quarter outlook, we expect sales to be in the $2.7 billion to $2.8 billion range, margin in the low 8% range, EPS of about $1.50. Free cash flow will be negative in the first quarter by about $100 million, similar to what it was in 2014. And the first quarter book-to-bill ratio looks like it's going to be about 0.95x. 
I'd like to make a couple of points about the MSI divestiture. Because it is not reflected in our guidance that we provided today, we'll include that in the guidance when the transaction closes, but I want to let you know what the impact would be ahead of that time. So once it closes, it'll become a discontinued operation, and that will lower income from continuing operations -- or results from continuing operations at the sales line by about $500 million. It'll increase consolidated margin by 10 to 15 basis points, and have about a neutral or no impact to our EPS and free cash flow guidance that we gave today for the year. 
So to conclude my financial review, while the DoD environment will, again, be challenging for this year, future budget levels are set to improve, with the budget likely upturning in FY '16, which begins in October 1. We're effectively managing for the DoD downcycle. The company is resilient and healthy. We're generating robust cash flow. And we'll continue to allocate our capital and our cash flow to increase shareholder value. 
Thank you, and we'll now begin the Q&A.

So we have a lot of opportunity to either do more acquisitions or buy back more of our common stock.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, M&A continues to be a key element of our growth strategy. But as you know, M&A for us has always been one opportunistic in that the targets or the candidates have to be available to acquire, and then they have to be fit with L-3. And lastly, and mor
componenttext:
Well, M&A continues to be a key element of our growth strategy. But as you know, M&A for us has always been one opportunistic in that the targets or the candidates have to be available to acquire, and then they have to be fit with L-3. And lastly, and more -- most importantly, good economic returns on the investment. 
So clearly, we'd like to do more acquisitions, but it's going to be subject to those 3 factors that I just talked about: Opportunity, fit and economic returns.

componenttext:
Okay, great. And the NSS segment, in particular, Mike put up a 3% margin. I realized it's 200 basis points of headwind that are probably more one-off than not. But still, obviously, the trend line of reducing the margin profile kind of every quarter over the last 4 quarters, then you get kind of to the end of the year, and you're pointing a little bit up for next year, but still below where you thought you were going to start this year. 
So just that business, as it sits today, is it still the same business that you thought it was going to be? Is it still a business that kind of -- is the place it should be?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, this whole segment of the budget services namely has come under heavy pressure on the margins due in part to the better buying power strategy and more competitions, more players willing to buy business, just the overall competitive environment, Myle
componenttext:
Well, this whole segment of the budget services namely has come under heavy pressure on the margins due in part to the better buying power strategy and more competitions, more players willing to buy business, just the overall competitive environment, Myles. So we'd rather not see it that way. And candidly, if there's not an improvement over the next year or 2, this one may be one that we would choose to part with. But right now, we don't think that makes sense because we think prices are probably lower than we'd like to see for it to make sense for us. And we still see strong growth in the cyber area. And we've won a bunch of new contracts in that area. 
I mean, the new business has been robust, to say the least. The disappointment is, it's at margins that we are not interested in. We're not interested in 5% businesses. We're interested in 10% and better. And there will become a point in time we are going to lose interest in pursuing it any further. 
So yes, we have our eye on it. And we're doing everything we can do to try to keep the costs as low as possible and get the margins up. But when that becomes absolutely pointless, I'm sure you'll see a change in strategy here.

componenttextpreview: Sure, Joe. It's Ralph. So what we explained in the discussion in the earnings release was that there were some high-margin international sales that slid out of the fourth quarter into the first half of 2015. So there's 2 contracts in particular. One, we
componenttext:
Sure, Joe. It's Ralph. So what we explained in the discussion in the earnings release was that there were some high-margin international sales that slid out of the fourth quarter into the first half of 2015. 
So there's 2 contracts in particular. One, we've already been selected. It's an FMS contract, and there has been delays in getting it contracted through the U.S. Air Force, but we expect to book that order in the next month or 2. And then, there's another contract which we expect to be sole-sourced on, and that's likely will be booked in the second quarter. So we still expect those high-margin orders and sales to occur. They're just -- they're going to be happening later than we expected at the time of our last guidance update for '14. 
But no doubt, the margins guidance that we gave for 2015 in NSS is contingent upon booking and converting those orders into sales that I just talked about.
