headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Allison. Good morning, and thanks for joining us for L-3's Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With me are Michael Strianese, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Ralph D'Ambrosio, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. After
componenttext:
Thanks, Allison. Good morning, and thanks for joining us for L-3's Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. With me are Michael Strianese, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and Ralph D'Ambrosio, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. After their formal remarks, management will be available to take your questions.  
Please note that during this call, management will reiterate forward-looking statements that were made in the press release issued this morning. Please refer to this press release as well as the company's SEC filings for a more detailed description of the factors that may cause actual results to differ materially from those anticipated. Please also note that this call is being simultaneously broadcast over the Internet.
I would now like to turn the call over to Mike Strianese. Mike, please go ahead.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. Thank you. Thanks for joining us for our third quarter conference call. Overall we had solid operating results with higher operating margins in our Electronic Systems, Aerospace Systems and Communication Systems segments. We also
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. Thank you. Thanks for joining us for our third quarter conference call. 
Overall we had solid operating results with higher operating margins in our Electronic Systems, Aerospace Systems and Communication Systems segments. We also continue to make good progress on the divestiture of our national security solutions business and expect to make an announcement by year-end. This quarter, we recognized the noncash goodwill impairment charge related to NSS. Ralph will provide more details on that charge in his remarks. 
Yesterday, as I'm sure you've seen, we announced that Chris Chubasik has joined L-3 as President and CEO. Chris has over 30 years of operational experience in the aerospace and defense industry and is a terrific addition to our already strong leadership team and we're all very pleased to have him at L-3. His actions reflect our commitment to positioning our portfolio to sharpen our focus on our higher returning electronics communications and ISR businesses where we have market-leading positions. These are areas that are critical to the security of our nation. 
Further, we continue to evaluate our portfolio for additional opportunities to improve our strategic position and create value for our shareholders. As we have stated, we're looking to focus on businesses with stronger margin profiles and higher returns in markets where we have leading positions and the strongest potential for growth. We expect to redeploy capital generated by these and future strategic initiatives into our existing portfolio as well as the fund acquisitions that drive the stronger returns.
While we continue to face certain macro challenges, we are laser-focused on execution and investing in areas that will improve the overall performance of our portfolio. In many areas of our business, our efforts are yielding positive results, as reflected in some important contract wins in the quarter and we have successfully expanded our customer base. 
Turning to our third quarter results, we had net sales of $2.8 billion, a decrease of 4% compared with the 2014 third quarter.
We delivered strong bottom line performance, thanks to our continued focus on pursuing higher margin business and disciplined course management. Our consolidated segment operating positions are improving and are better-than-expected at 10.2% for the quarter. And we're pleased about that. Funded orders for the quarter were $2.4 billion, which was a slight decrease year-over-year. And we ended the quarter with about $9.4 billion of funded backlog, with a book-to-bill ratio for the quarter of about 0.86 and 0.98 year-to-date.
During the quarter, we generated net cash from operating activities of $317 [ph] million, most of which we returned to shareholders.
We repurchased $259 million of our stock in the quarter and paid $52 million in dividends. Year-to-date, we've returned nearly $800 million in cash to shareholders.
Before I go through our wins for the quarter, I'd like to give an update on other key business items across the company. Our progress on the Head of State programs continues to meet our estimates and schedules as discussed on our second quarter call. Earlier this week, we successfully completed a key customer checkout flight. Our progress has been very encouraging. The new management team we put in place has been very focused on the program and we're seeing the results of their efforts every day.
Operationally, we're also taking steps to improve program performance and to create value for customers through continued investments in R&D and new technology development. As an example of our R&D efforts, our focus on innovation helped us secure a broadband communications systems contract for Apache helicopter. This is the case where we devised a technology enhancement on behalf of our customer and delivered an unprecedented command and control capability. This is an area where I would call it thought leadership for our team, where we identified a potential solution for our customer and developed it on our own that really enables an unprecedented man to unmanned teaming capacity that until now has not been available. So we're very proud of that accomplishment and the customer is very happy with the solution.
In terms of M&A, our goal is to complement L-3's existing business with new acquisitions and expand our market share, broaden our offerings and bring us new customers. Our recent acquisition of Forseks [ph] is a great example of that. We've worked with this company for 7 years and it adds new capabilities and customers, which allows us to compete in broader markets.
Forseks [ph] specializes in the processing, exploitation and dissemination of information. This technology enables a rapid decision making ability from the data collected by our sensor. This complements our wide-area imagery and sensor expertise that we will be able to integrate Forseks software into our existing EOI sensors, cards and subsystems. In short, we've transformed L-3 from a sensor supplier to an information supplier in a very strategic ISR market area.
Plus this also creates a software upgrade opportunities with our installed base of thousands of L-3 sensor products.
In addition, our acquisition of CTC earlier this year has continued to prove a strong fit. As we discussed last quarter, the commercial aviation training market is enjoying record demand for professionally trained pilots and forecast showed that over 550,000 pilots will be required in the next 20 years. The combined CTC aviation and Link U.K. businesses are performing well and the synergies between these 2 companies are benefiting customers around the world. We've had unanimous positive responses from our customers and industry on this new capability. As a result, we expanded our pilot training in our sensor in Thailand and are developing our business in the U.K. We're now providing training on our A320 and 737 simulators at the recently launched quality training facility outside of Gatwick airport in London with plans to expand our position in this market.
This is a great example of our M&A strategy and we are actively looking at acquiring businesses that will meet our criteria for both margin expansion and top line growth and enhance our existing portfolio of market-leading technologies.
Finally, I'm very pleased to report that we've been recognized, once again, with Cogswell awards for outstanding industrial security practices at 3 L-3 facilities. We insist on the highest standards in all aspect of our operations and we are honored to receive these awards. Our approach in this area has been to make our industrial security program a business discriminator as it continues to become more important in our current environment. 
Now I'd like to discuss some of those wins we've had across our defense commercial aviation and international businesses.
So on the defense side, we were focused on DoD priority areas including ISR communications, sensors and the classified space. With regard to the defense budget, while we continue to believe that we are nearing the end of an extended period of uncertainty, we're experiencing a delay in the anticipated DoD budget update. However, the bipartisan budget agreement provides 2 years of funding with an increase of $38 billion in fiscal '16 from the '15 DoD budget. This is a good fit for L-3 as it enables our long-term planning ability and advances the contract award process. We also have quick reaction capabilities that are sought after as well as ISR upgrade, maintenance and weapon systems sustainment expertise.
The agreement will facilitate this work and is expected to translate into increased activity from programs that we already support. In the third quarter, we received some strategic awards that will further grow our business. As I mentioned earlier, we've been selected to provide our broadband comps system for the U.S. Army's Apache helicopter. This was a major win for us where we designed a spiral developed a new solution based on an earlier combat proof of design. This is what I just described as manned unmanned teaming expertise.
It's noticed, Novel TX under that program and we will provide at the Apache with its first ever video and broadband data transmission with multiple universal unmanned platforms.
We were also awarded a contract to missionize 2 C-130 aircraft for the U.S. Coast Guard with options missionize 10 additional C-130 aircraft that provide ground flight test support for them. This is a great programming for our team at Waco.
We were selected to supply our key management infrastructure for the intelligence community as part of the last mile portable key load program. This is a 10-year program that extends our leadership position and information assurance. 
This quarter, we are on the spot on 2 ID/IQ contracts, the U.S. air forces TSA 3 and Agile acquisition programs. 
Finally, in our military simulation business, we received a contract extension for our C-17 simulation program. 
For commercial aviation, we're at the beginning of a growth cycle driven primarily by expansions in developing regions and localized carriers with Asia dominating. It's predicted that the worldwide fleet size will more than double in the next 20 years. 
As the air transport OEMs continue to forecast increased production rates, directives such as the 2020 ADSP out mandate continue to drive growth in the U.S. and Europe. We have a strong commercial aviation business and we have increased our efforts to capitalize on opportunities in this market.
In our training business Boeing ordered its first 787 Reality 7 full flight simulator. We also received notification that we have been selected by 2 airlines and an OEM for new simulators. These sales will represent a major step in expanding our base in strategically important regions.
In aviation security, we're concentrating on upgrading our technology and recently received funding from the TSA for software development and algorithms for our examiner systems as well as an order for France for our check bagger systems. The use of our probation system continues to expand globally. We are participating in key product demonstrations at several airports in Japan aimed at the adoption of systems there. 
In addition, our nuclear scan system for carry-on baggage will soon be deployed at major -- at a major international airport. That is another example of our folks identifying a solution that they believe to be widely accepted. Everybody knows how troubling it is to have liquids taken out of your carry-on bags or take out computers and turn them on. What we've been able to do utilizing computed tomography or CT and advanced algorithm -- detection algorithms, we've been able to allow travelers to leave liquids and electronics in their bags as they make their way through security checkpoints. And the system will detect whether there's a bad substance or energetic material that doesn't belong there. So as we all know, using the machine to do the detection is a heck of a lot more efficient and should keep lines moving better and provide much better detection capability.
In the international space, part of our strategy is growing our international sales, which we know can be a lumpy business, but it still remains a focus area for us. I'd like to highlight a few of the wins we had during the quarter. 
Our integrated platform management system was selected by the Royal Canadian Navy as part of a major vessel conversion project. We achieved the first international sale of our Catapan [ph] global encryption product. This marks an important win for our encryption business as we continue to support to secure communication requirements for a variety of international government customers. 
We also received continued funding of legacy programs, including Argentina C-130 and the U.K. Airseeder [ph] program.
Now let's turn to the outlook for the remainder of 2015. We have positive momentum as we move into the fourth quarter and are capitalizing on this with solid execution and program performance. We continue to explore possible additions to the L-3 portfolio that we believe are a good fit and that further strengthen our core business, improve margin and sales profiles and generate strong cash flow for the company.
Our goal is to expand our market share, extend our product offerings and capabilities, attract new customers and of course grow shareholder value.
We also remain committed to investing in R&D and are encouraged that our investments are paying dividends. We target key areas to keep our technology portfolio fresh and relevant and will continue to invest in this critical area going forward. 
That said, L-3 is well-positioned in several DoD priority areas, including persistent ISR and protected communications, unmanned systems, space and the classified arena.
We're confident that our growth strategies, together with our strong balance sheet and disciplined capital allocation strategy, positions us well to drive value to shareholders. We'll end this year on a strong note well prepared and energize driving improvement and continue to reposition the portfolio into 2016.
We provided our initial outlook in the release this morning. We'll release our guidance and provide further perspective for 2016 at an upcoming Investor Day, which we will be hosting in New York City on Tuesday, December 8.
So I'm going to turn it over to Ralph now for some more details on the financials. And then we'll be back and take your questions. So with that, Ralph?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. I'll discuss some details about the third quarter results and then review our 2015 guidance update and the preliminary outlook for 2016. We had a strong operational performance for the third quarter with adjusted diluted EPS of $2.09, w
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike. I'll discuss some details about the third quarter results and then review our 2015 guidance update and the preliminary outlook for 2016. 
We had a strong operational performance for the third quarter with adjusted diluted EPS of $2.09, which was better than what our outlook was for the third quarter. It was driven primarily by higher operating margin as well as lower taxes, which more than offset softer-than-expected sales. Free cash flow was $263 million for the quarter and also very solid.
Adjusted diluted EPS excludes gains and losses on business divestitures and the noncash NSS goodwill impairment charge. 
Third quarter's consolidated sales were $2,817,000,000 [ph] and declined 1% organically. Sales were about $130 million left in our third quarter guidance and that was due to delays and reductions in international and commercial business.
NSS had another disappointing quarter and missed a plane again, primarily due to continued delays in converting higher-margin international and commercial business, which had similarly impacted NSS's first half results.
A smaller negative impact for NSS has been tasking delays on various DoD ID/IQ contract vehicles.
As a result, we reassessed and reduced NSS future outlook for sales and operating margins, and this triggered the NSS goodwill impairment charge. 
Third quarter operating margins were better than we anticipated in every other segment, with margins for Electronic Systems and Communication Systems moving higher and exhibiting the improvement trends which we've been articulating. 
Aerospace Systems margin rebounded sharply from the second quarter and it benefited from some items that we do not expect to recur in the fourth quarter or next year. 
In the ISR systems sector, we had sales volume and better contract performance on 3 large international contracts that are nearing completion, and those raised margin over 200 basis points for the segment.
In the logistics solutions sector, we received an $8 million request for equitable adjustment to recover a portion of the prior year cost overruns on a previous Army C-12 contract, which raised margin another 80 [ph] basis points for the segment.
Excluding these items, Aerospace Systems third quarter margin would have been less than 7%. 
With respect to our 2015 guidance update, with tightened our adjusted EPS range and maintained the midpoint at $6.85. The lower operating income expectation for NSS is being offset by a combination of higher margin than the other segments and a lower tax rate.
We also reduced our consolidated sales at the midpoint by $100 million to $11,450,000,000 [ph], and that's due to the international and commercial sales trend that I talked about a few minutes ago, which mostly impacts Electronic Systems and NSS.  And we also reduced consolidated operating margin by a modest 10 basis points to 8.3%.
We maintained our free cash flow estimate of $850 million for the year. And with respect to our capital allocation, we are assuming $740 million of share repurchases for 2015, after shifting $60 million to pay for the Force X acquisition earlier this month. We still plan to repay $300 [ph] million of debt in the fourth quarter.
And for the last point on the 2015 guidance, we now expect the book-to-bill ratio for the year to be approximately 0.97, and that again is due to the lower expected international and commercial orders that I talked about, which will impact 2016 sales. 
So scrolling forward to our preliminary outlook for 2016, we expect consolidated sales to decline about 3% to $11.1 billion. And this estimate assumes an organic sales decline of about 1.5%. The major change since we last discussed the 2016 sales trends, again is that now we expect international sales to decline about 15% in 2016 versus 2015. 
We still expect our U.S. Government sales, including the DoD, to be flat organically versus '15. And commercial sales are expected to grow about 7%. 
With respect to the international sales, I'd like to add that we continue to expect foreign military business to be a long-term growth driver for L-3, however as you know, the international business is inherently lumpy and less predictable than the U.S. DoD business. And international is growing at a very nice pace over the last several years. It's going to take a pause in 2016 before we start to grow it again after next year.
At the segment level, we expect organic sales growth to be 1% to 2% for Electronic Systems. And that will be offset by declines of about 4% for each of Aerospace Systems and Communication Systems. 
For operating margin, we expect consolidated margin to increase 80 basis points to about 9.1% next year with the margins increasing in all 4 segments.
The margin progressions are on target for Electronic Systems to the mid-12% range and for Communication Systems to the low 10% range. However, margins are below our objectives for Aerospace Systems and NSS. 
With respect to Aerospace Systems, the margin for next year is expected to be in the low 6% range. And it's a very different story when you look at the 3 sectors in Aerospace Systems. So ISR Systems sector will have margins for 2016 that will continue to be very solid at about 10%, but they will decline versus 2015 due to those lower international sales and those contract ending that I talked about earlier. As well as the final run-off in the Afghanistan drawdown sales. 
Aircraft Systems sector margins will swing to profitability in 2016 following the head of state aircraft losses that we incurred in the first half of 2015, but those margins are only going to improve to about 3%. And last week, logistics solutions margin will remain about 2%, as it continues to wrestle with the pricing pressures, LPGA and reduced flight hours. 
The tax rate for next year is expected to be 31%, and that assumes no federal or any tax credit. And you can be assured that we're tasking our tax advice -- tax advice is to drive that rate down again like we did in 2016 [ph] -- 2015. 
With respect to free cash flow. We expect it to be at $850 [ph] million for 2016, the same as it is expected to be for 2015. And what's happening there is that higher operating income is being offset by larger income tax payments due to the tax rate going up. Our planned share repurchases for 2016 start at $500 million. And all of these items that I just discussed for next year, in terms of the outlook, calculate to EPS of about $7.25 for 2016.
So to conclude with my financial review, L-3 is in the process of positive transition. We're focused on program performance and margin expansion and making good progress, especially in Electronic Systems and Communication Systems. We are also transforming our portfolio of businesses to strengthen the company and enhance our financial performance. We continue to generate solid free cash flow and are allocating it to increase shareholder value. 
We acknowledge that we have work to do. We can do better and we will. And finally, I'd also like to say that I look forward to working with Chris and I'm pleased that he joined L-3. 
With that, thank you. And we'll go to the Q&A.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Robert Spingarn from Credit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from Robert Spingarn from Credit Suisse.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So well, congrats to Chris for joining the team. We'll all look forward to working with him again. And Mike, I wanted to go back to something that you focused on your monologue with regard to the hardware, the electronics businesses and your focus there o
componenttext: So well, congrats to Chris for joining the team. We'll all look forward to working with him again. And Mike, I wanted to go back to something that you focused on your monologue with regard to the hardware, the electronics businesses and your focus there on the businesses that really are your core strength. Could you talk about the distinction between focusing on expanding share there and revenues and then also what you can do with the margins?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, Rob. Well, a good example of expanding the 2 acquisitions we did this year the CDC 1, which took the existing simulator hardware business, and now build that out to not only include the sale of the device or the simulator to potential customers
componenttext:
Yes. Sure, Rob. Well, a good example of expanding the 2 acquisitions we did this year the CDC 1, which took the existing simulator hardware business, and now build that out to not only include the sale of the device or the simulator to potential customers, but the potential to sell training by the hour, which we're hearing customers is asking more and more every day. And it's a very compelling business model when you look at it in terms of the margins it delivers and our capacity to be able to deliver that globally. You couple that with the demand for pilots over the next 10 to 20 years, it looks like the very good story for us, being able to not only deliver a state of the art devices, but wrapping the service element around that of trainers has made it a very strong business for us and we look forward to that growing over the future.
On top of that, the Forseks [ph] is a good example, again of taking an existing leading product, our ERR chart, which is virtually on every manned and unmanned platform that has an ERR chart. And baking into that, software capability to do more analytical work on the data that the sensor gathers. So not just providing raw imagery, if you will, but it's actually providing actionable information and putting the processing capacity on the platform and getting it off the ground, if you will. So getting quicker information into the hands of the war fighter. So that also will expand the market by taking an existing product and expanding its capability. We also have an installed base of those products, which gives us a ready market to go out and provide upgrades to. On the margin side, [indiscernible] expand margins are won by targeting businesses in our acquisition program that are better margins or have that potential, but also working through our portfolio of businesses with an eye towards either consolidation or other forms of cost take out, whether it's in the facility area, better supply-chain management, overall better program execution is kind of an obvious one there. But generally, the entire cost model is being challenged in virtually every business units. So we've been very clear with our leadership teams in all our groups and divisions that margin expansion is going to be a criteria that they're going to be measured on. And we're happy with the response we're getting from them. They understand it and are being very responsive to us.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just one more quick one for Ralph. You talked about the international declining next year, but then inverting back up in '17, it sounds like. Could you talk a little bit more about how you have that kind of visibility? What's going on and what speci
componenttext: Okay. Just one more quick one for Ralph. You talked about the international declining next year, but then inverting back up in '17, it sounds like. Could you talk a little bit more about how you have that kind of visibility? What's going on and what specifically gives you the confidence that we'll see the recovery in '17, and what that looks like?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we have several large pursuits that we're going after over the next year. And we have to book those to be sure in order to return the international business to sales growth in 2017. And a lot of those are in the Aerospace Systems, ISR sector, as wel
componenttext: Well, we have several large pursuits that we're going after over the next year. And we have to book those to be sure in order to return the international business to sales growth in 2017. And a lot of those are in the Aerospace Systems, ISR sector, as well as in Electronic Systems with some opportunities in Comp Systems for additional comp terminals. So we have work to do, but we're focused on it and we expect to return the international business to growth again after next year.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Cai Von Rumohr from Cowen & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Cai Von Rumohr from Cowen & Company.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you give a little more color on communications next year? Is that -- and I didn't catch whether or not that's down 4% or that's going to be flattish and what's driving it.
componenttext: Could you give a little more color on communications next year? Is that -- and I didn't catch whether or not that's down 4% or that's going to be flattish and what's driving it.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I said that we expect sales to decline about 4% in comp systems next year and there are really 2 items driving that. So we booked a large terminal order earlier this year for Australia, which was about $80 [ph] million. And we're going to expect
componenttext: Sure. So I said that we expect sales to decline about 4% in comp systems next year and there are really 2 items driving that. So we booked a large terminal order earlier this year for Australia, which was about $80 [ph] million. And we're going to expect to ship that order this year. And while we do see follow-ons there, we won't get the next quarter until late in 2016 or early in 2017. So that's going to cause an $80 million drop in international sales in Communication Systems segment. That's when the items affecting the international profile I just talked about with respect to a previous question from Rob. And then secondly, within Communication Systems, we do about $300 million a year or so on power devices or TWTs that are used in a variety of platforms, including in satellites. And there's been a slow down in new commercial satellite orders this year, or think it's only 7 or so that have been ordered year-to-date, which compared to a normal year of about 20 or so SATs. And for that reason, we expect to have about $60 million to $70 million sales decline next year in that business, in the TWT business, which is in Communication Systems. And that's also affecting the sales next year. And what that is offsetting is growth in the DoD business, especially in the broadband comps or comps systems West. And that business has been recovering very nicely the last 1.5 year or so. We overcame the European implementation issues that we had there in the last couple of years. And it looks like it's going to be on a nice growth path going forward the next several years. So that's what's happening in comp systems, Cai.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just one last one. So Mike, you talked about other strategic actions. Can you give us any sense in terms of the magnitude or the time frame by which you hope to have made those decisions?
componenttext: Just one last one. So Mike, you talked about other strategic actions. Can you give us any sense in terms of the magnitude or the time frame by which you hope to have made those decisions?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Cai. We've been through, as I was in, top to bottom review of the entire portfolio with our board this fall. And again with objectives we've been talking about, businesses where we have significant competitive discriminators, which are typically for
componenttext: Sure, Cai. We've been through, as I was in, top to bottom review of the entire portfolio with our board this fall. And again with objectives we've been talking about, businesses where we have significant competitive discriminators, which are typically for us in the electronic space, and then had good profiles for future growth and margin expansion. And businesses that didn't fit that profile have been looked at more carefully with an eye towards potentially divesting. So in terms of timing, I would say we're looking at over the next year or so. This is a process that we look at regularly and will necessarily change as things change around us. We'll adopt or adapt to those changes and adopt whatever strategies we think are necessary for time to ensure our continued margin expansion and growth. But in terms of size, I really can't give you a number off the top of my head in terms of sales volume. But to tell you that everything that you would think of that is performing below our composite in margins is being looked at carefully. It's not just by numbers, if you will, I mean there's a little more that goes into the analysis. It's the future growth rate where the customers are going to require in the future, requirements are going to be in technology, et cetera, et cetera. But we think that this process will continue and there will be further adjustments as we go forward.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Well, we expect diluted shares in the P&L to be about 80 [ph] -- just on the 82 million [ph] shares. And we include that in the guidance, Howard. The share count in terms of actual share outstanding will be well below 80 million shares at the end of the year.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: That's where I was driving towards. And then last with the initiatives. What you've seen so far with the budget and I realized there is still a lot that needs to be allocated, Mike. How do you see sort of your conversations with your customers going so that you can get a sense of some stability in your outlook on some of the major programs you have? Typically, just for example. I mean, Compass Call for example. The language in the -- I think it was in the bill actually favored more money as opposed to the declines that have occurred. So maybe there's a couple of differences that you can elaborate on?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, that's one of the brighter lights, Howard. But it's been moving around for a while. And I can tell you from a macro perspective, whether it's ISR, protected communications, the classified, the areas we've been focusing on are areas we're encour
componenttext: Well, yes, that's one of the brighter lights, Howard. But it's been moving around for a while. And I can tell you from a macro perspective, whether it's ISR, protected communications, the classified, the areas we've been focusing on are areas we're encouraged by what we're seeing the budget, in terms of clarity over future funding is going to be. But I'm not really going to take it down at a program level at this point because it's just too many moving parts right now. And as you also probably noticed, the good piece of the increase in the budget is really going towards some of the newer platforms. And while we do enjoy content on many of those platforms, they're just not drivers for our entire business, where we're more driven by, again, persistent ISR, effective comps, night vision, requirements et cetera. Those are areas where we've been very encouraged with everything we've seen so far.

componenttext: Onboard takes succession planning seriously and regularly reviews the matter. I'm very excited about the opportunities ahead for L-3. And I'm delighted to have a partner like Chris onboard to help Ralph and I execute in our strategic mission. I think given his 30 year experience in this industry and his proven track record, it will really translate into a very, very strong capability at L-3 and will help us move out on our plan on an accelerated basis. So we're very pleased with how it looks going forward for us. And it would be the typical functions one would expect from a Chief Operating Officer. So Group Presidents, supply chain management, proposals, etc. It would be the traditional areas one would think about for a Chief Operating Officer.

componenttext: Sure. And I think he's a great fit here culturally, and those in our business as one would expect. He's had very capable hands to add to Ralph and myself that is on the same page in terms of the things we need to get accomplished here moving the company forward.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of -- sort of structural, big picture kind of question here. The emphasis on margin and return in that respect, have you changed any of the incentives, incentive structures or level down? Or do you envision there will be any overall change f
componenttext: Just a couple of -- sort of structural, big picture kind of question here. The emphasis on margin and return in that respect, have you changed any of the incentives, incentive structures or level down? Or do you envision there will be any overall change from the more sort of EPS TSR leaning structure that's been there? And then with respect to Chris and the difference between kind of L-3's kind of more decentralized structure and what we see in the other big primes. Is there a signal here of the change of how L-3 run to attack that cost?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: First of all, in terms of the incentives. The answer is yes since we are trying to encourage that behavior of margin expansion and cost control. We are baking that into some of the measures that we have going forward. Even though we might say that while t
componenttext: First of all, in terms of the incentives. The answer is yes since we are trying to encourage that behavior of margin expansion and cost control. We are baking that into some of the measures that we have going forward. Even though we might say that while their EPS or TSR centric they'll include those elements. But if you look at what the plan will be going through the basis for an incentive agreement going into that plan will be a reasonable level of margin expansion. So in that sense, it's in there. It's always been in there to some degree. Each successive plan has some level of margin expansion. It's just becoming more of a focal point going forward. And then, in terms of L-3 structurally, I'm very mindful and careful not to take some of the very things that have made the company successful in the past and throw that away. To decentralize structure in many regards works well. We do think that a little bit more controls sort of centralized sense could make -- could be appropriate at this point in the life of the company that we do want to make sure we have the strongest oversight in place, that we can have over our business units and that's done in conjunction with our Group presidents. But the answer is no, we still tend to have a significant level of economy in our business unit level. We believe that, that decision making is made best when it's done closest to the customer, but as long as it's done within the parameters that we lay out for our people. And with that in mind, I think adding Chris and his experience with the team will kind of enhance that whole process.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So first off, I wanted to ask you something. Recently, you were among the 12 contractors Down selected for their Air Force training program TSA 3. I haven't seen a lot on this task force program. The numbers look like $21 billion over 10 years. So I want
componenttext: So first off, I wanted to ask you something. Recently, you were among the 12 contractors Down selected for their Air Force training program TSA 3. I haven't seen a lot on this task force program. The numbers look like $21 billion over 10 years. So I want to know if you could discuss this a bit. Is this a program where multiple winners are going to be selected out of the 12, or just down to a very few? I'm just trying to find out if this is a needle mover for you and when do you think it could be awarded.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is very new, Rich. I expect that the past quarters you'll start to see them next year. And it would move the needle if we want several of them at the same time, for sure. But there are multiple winners here. And I think when you get to this place, it
componenttext: This is very new, Rich. I expect that the past quarters you'll start to see them next year. And it would move the needle if we want several of them at the same time, for sure. But there are multiple winners here. And I think when you get to this place, it becomes a cost shoot out as they say, because you have a bunch of capable winners on the program. So, I mean, we can give updates as we get into next year on it. But it's certainly not going to move the needle this year at all, no matter what they do from a project basis, if you will or task quarter basis. Even our past quarters this year wouldn't make much of a difference. It would have to be things we see awarded for early next year.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just quickly here. At logistics solutions, I was interested in your comment about competitive pressure. Looking ahead, do you expect pricing pressure to continue? Is this a situation where you have cost to take out here that you can maintai
componenttext: Okay. And then just quickly here. At logistics solutions, I was interested in your comment about competitive pressure. Looking ahead, do you expect pricing pressure to continue? Is this a situation where you have cost to take out here that you can maintain margin? Or is this going to be a source of margin pressure for you going forward?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean by virtue of their lower margins already pressuring home the overall margin profile, but we don't expect margins to go any lower from that 2% that I talked about. In fact, we do expect that we'll be able to modestly improve them through cost
componenttext: Well, I mean by virtue of their lower margins already pressuring home the overall margin profile, but we don't expect margins to go any lower from that 2% that I talked about. In fact, we do expect that we'll be able to modestly improve them through cost take out activities, et cetera. But it's doubtful that we can't forget where we're moving the entire company margin-wise. And with respect to the LPTA, there's certainly a lot of talk about the pendulum swinging away from it. But all we're seeing is talk right now. And the actual RFPs and the award selection criteria, LPTA is still a -- the main criteria on a lot of these competitions. And I think its a function of the fact that even though the budgets for the U.S. Defense Department are going to turn upward now, they're still -- we're still in a constrained situation. So there's definitely room for more budget. And what we hear from a lot of our elected leaders talking about that hopefully they can bring that to fruition in the next couple of years.

componenttext: Sure, I can do more than roughly size it. I can give you some more precision there, Howard. So -- I mean, George. So that would put the segment sales in the $3.9 billion to $4 billion range, in a way those spreads across the 3 sectors. It's almost $2.1 billion in ISR systems, Aircraft Systems would be just under $700 million. And Logistics Solutions, just under $1.2 billion.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's pretty good. And then in aerospace, you commented that logistics would be hard-pressed to get the margins up. But do we have upside in the aerospace margin after we get rid of that Head of State program, which I think you said the last deliver
componenttext: Yes, that's pretty good. And then in aerospace, you commented that logistics would be hard-pressed to get the margins up. But do we have upside in the aerospace margin after we get rid of that Head of State program, which I think you said the last delivery is '17?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the answer is it depends, George. It depends on our ability to win new business, particularly in the platform integration division at Waco. To replace those head of the state sales and also to R&Eplace the PIII sales that have been declining for a w
componenttext: Well, the answer is it depends, George. It depends on our ability to win new business, particularly in the platform integration division at Waco. To replace those head of the state sales and also to R&Eplace the PIII sales that have been declining for a while. And someone earlier talked about -- asked about the conference call. And that's also a Waco program where we're doing about $80 million a year now and that's down from about $140 million a year a few years ago. And that's because of what's been happening with respect to reducing the fleet size there. So to the extent that we can bring new business in and we'll definitely be able to improve those margins. But that's something that we're focused on as well in terms of new business development. But that's the threshold to your question there.

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And for you, Mike. Are these 2 sectors -- subsectors the are that you're primary looking at to divest some of the lower-margin businesses? Because I assume, this big range of margin with the programs in these sectors?
componenttext: And for you, Mike. Are these 2 sectors -- subsectors the are that you're primary looking at to divest some of the lower-margin businesses? Because I assume, this big range of margin with the programs in these sectors?

headline: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's right, George. So there is a big range. It's not just going to be the margins and outlook for the business going forward without giving the wrong direction. If you think logistics, which keeps coming up, yes, margins have been lower. Hurt by compet
componenttext:
That's right, George. So there is a big range. It's not just going to be the margins and outlook for the business going forward without giving the wrong direction. If you think logistics, which keeps coming up, yes, margins have been lower. Hurt by competitive issues as well as the overall downward pressure on margins, however, if you look at where the U.S. service people are operating, it's all over the world. And logistics happens to be a discriminator that makes that possible. It's a key enabler for our militaries. It's having a very robust logistics environment around them. So it's something that I think may get renewed focus by the DoD. But again, we here are focused on doing whatever it is we need to do to drive value. So it's the whole package, whether it's margin, top line growth, the combination of the two. So it's all in the table. And we will take those actions, George. 
So just concluding, moving forward, we plan -- we believe the actions that we have taken and the plans we put in place reflect our customer's priorities and give us a clear path to significantly improve our revenue and earnings performance over time. At its core, our strategy for discipline growth is simple and straightforward. We are repositioning our portfolio and investing in our businesses, our people and our technologies, as well as levering our cash flow generation to maintain market leadership in our core businesses and return cash to our shareholders. 
We're focused on higher return businesses in markets where we maintain leading positions. We're excited about L-3's progress and prospects for enhancing and expanding our defense electronics, ISR and communications businesses, areas where we have market-leading positions and that represent the core of L-3. 
We're committed to long-term strategic growth and performance and we'll continue to work to deliver value for all shareholders. As I've mentioned a couple of times now, we plan on hosting an Investor Day in New York on December 8. We will provide additional color and detail in our strategy, our ongoing business transformation and our key initiatives for 2016, and I look forward to seeing you all there and continuing this dialogue. And our board will be there. Many of the members of the board will be present as well. So thanks again for joining us this morning and on the call. And we look forward to speaking to you in a couple of weeks. Thank you.
